            PROTECTION ENHANCEMENT PROJECT,TF096854-Jordan Integrated Social Services

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Social Protection
            Enhancement Project for Jordan were as follows: outcomes
            were highly unsatisfactory, risk to development outcome was
            high, Bank performance was unsatisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: problem projects can become successful, but they
            require intensive implementation support and a thorough
            reflection as to the very issues that affect implementation.
            Implementation support for investment lending can be used
            effectively to reinforce sectoral policy dialogue, but,
            unless there is clear commitment by the government to
            sectoral policy reform, it should not be the driving force
            behind that dialogue. One size does not fit all with respect
            to targeting of social protection assistance. Proxy means
            testing (PMT) may be considered the best standard in
            targeting methodology, specifically for its ability to
            predict poverty status and ranking all beneficiaries in a
            given registry. Combining what is in effect policy
            conditionality in an investment loan or credit or grant
            should only be done in the context of a clear commitment by
            the government. Poor institutional arrangements can have an
            adverse impact on the prospects for success in project
            implementation. Social protection projects, especially those
            that aim at increasing the efficiency of existing systems,
            in particular cash transfer programs, face large challenges
            when exogenous factors impact the livelihoods of the covered
            population. Building institutional capacity in implementing
            agencies presents challenges between utilizing government
            civil servants or relying on external consultants.
